text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I am Ann Reardon
and today we are making a makeup cake!

Yes, I read all your requests in the comments
and we've got a little bag with brushes, nail

polishes, eyeshadow, lipstick - all edible
of course.
Give this video a thumbs up if you like makeup.

To start with we want to bake 1 and half quantities
of my rich chocolate cake.
Bake that in a tray and an 8" round tin.
Now to make our makeup brushes.

Take some acetate and roll it up fairly tightly
and secure that into place with some tape.

You can make that straight or you can make
them wider at one end.

Place some baking paper at the bottom of a
cup, just push it down there, and then put

the acetate tubes that you just made into
the cup.

Then use a piping bag to fill the tubes with
tempered chocolate.

If you don't know how to temper chocolate
look up the chocolate secrets video on the

HowToCookThat channel and it will explain
all that to you.

For the smaller brushes you can use straws
and pipe them full of chocolate too.

Once they are set you can cut the tape and
unroll that acetate to reveal your chocolate
brush handle.

Trim them to the size you want them to be
and then brush those with gold luster dust
using a dry paint brush.

Any excess dust here you can just sweep up
on your baking paper and use that again later.

For the top of the brush roll a ball then
flatten it between your thumb and finger on
the tops and the sides.

Then use a little bit of water to add it to
the handle.

And use the tip of your knife to draw lines
from the base to the top of the brush so it
looks like bristles.

Use a skewer to poke some holes in the end,
then if you want to you can add some colour

to the brush, powdered food colouring works
well for this or coloured luster dust works
well too.

To get the chocolate out of the straws what
you need to do is cut gently down one side,

obviously you don't want to cut to hard or
you'll cut right through it.
And peel off the straw from the chocolate.

For these smaller brushes we are just going
to put the metallic dust just at one end.

Then add a little bit of white fondant for
the tip and draw lines on it just like we
did for the bigger brush.

For our nail polish we want the base to look
like glass so put some isomalt crystals in
a pan.

Isomalt is just a stable sugar that is really
good for decorating.
Keep it on high heat until it melts.
Then pour it into a silicone chocolate mold.

This is extremely hot so be very careful or
wear gloves.

Once they are cooled push them out of the
mold and you have this glass looking base
for your bottle.

Roll a ball of colour and then roll one end
between your hands to make it smaller at one
end.

Then place that onto the base and use your
thumbs and fingers to shape it to the size
of the bottom piece there.

For the lid roll a fat snake of black and
trim it off at each end.

Cut yourself a strip in the same colour as
the nail polish bottle and then wrap that
around the base of the lid.
Then stand it up and leave those to harden.

For our lipstick I want to make this out of
chocolate instead of out of fondant.
Take a finished lipstick and clean it thoroughly.

And then add some fondant into the centre
so it is not hollow.

Then make a little container, I've made mine
out of Lego and then fill it with re-useable
molding gel.

I'll put a link to that below because everyone
always asks where I get it from.

And place the lipstick upside down into the
gel.

And then to stop it floating up, add another
piece of Lego across the top and click it
on.
Once the gel is cooled it will be set.

Wriggle loose all your Lego bricks and then
pull them all off.

And then take the lipstick out of the mold
that we have just made.

Now all you need to do is fill that up with
tempered chocolate and tap it on the bench
really hard just to help minimise any air-bubbles.

And once that has set you can just push it
from the base until you can see the chocolate
and then just pull that out.

Use a knife to neaten up the base so it sits
flat when you have it upright.

And do the same at the top, we had a few little
air bubbles in there still so we'll just neaten
that up with a knife too.

Now brush that with gold or silver luster
dust or a combination of the two.

And for the coloured lipstick part just going
to roll a snake of fondant and trim it off
on an angle just like your new lipsticks look.

And then use your finger to smooth off the
edges of the cut.

Then add that to the top of the base, and
it has to be straight, you can't have a crooked

lipstick, so just take your time to straighten
it up from all angles.

Turn it around and check until it's looking
good.

For our round eyeshadows, these are really
easy.

What you need to do is cut a circle of black,
then indent it with a smaller circle in the
centre.
And brush the middle with luster dust.

This is even easier if you just leave that
smaller circle cutter on there when you're

brushing so it doesn't get on the outside
black.

For the eyeshadow palette roll out some white
fondant.
And then cut that into strips and then squares.

I am just using a piece of cardboard here
to make sure they are all the same size.

Next use some edible luster dust to brush
on colour to each square and you can mix those
together so you get a good range of colours.

Then use a ruler to cut a thin strip of black,
the same height as your white squares.

And then put a little water on the side of
your square, put a bit of black between the
two and join them together.

Continue to do that making three rows of four
eyeshadows.

Now dampen down the side of the rows and add
a longer strip of black between them and gently

push them together, careful not to squash
them out of shape.

Do the same on the other side, then just use
a knife to make sure your edges are nice and
straight.

Then add another small strip across the end
and then a flat piece for the applicator tray.

Use your knife just to trim that to size as
the rest of the palette.

Add another strip of black to each side of
the eyeshadow palette just using some water
to make it stick.
And some to the top and the bottom.

For the lid cut a piece that's the same size
as the base.

Again just using a ruler and a pizza cutter
to get nice straight edges.

You can make more of these trays, I'm going
to make another one with just rectangle strips
going across as well to go into the bag.

Then make a line, just indenting it - you're
not wanting to cut it all the way through,

you're just wanting to make a line for where
the rectangle of the mirror is going to be
in the lid.

Mix some silver luster dust with a little
alcohol and paint it over all over the mirror
area.

Now for the little applicator, roll a ball
of white and cut it in half.

Use your fingers to flatten it and shape it
in a bit for each end.

Roll a snake of black and brush it with metallic
luster dust to cover it.

Then place that in the middle of the applicator
tray.
And then add the tips to each end.

Take a skewer and very gently press little
dots all over it to give it a spongy texture.

Then you want to leave these overnight to
dry out a bit and they're easier to handle.

The next day make up a batch of buttercream
and add chilled ganache to make a beautiful
rich frosting.
Take your round cake and cut a strip.

And I'll put a sizing guide on the template
for you for this and for all of the makeup
pieces that we've already made.

Then cut more rectangles from the tray cake
in the sizes shown.

Then cut a cake board a little smaller than
the base cake and add some frosting on that,
just a little bit to stop the cake from slipping.

Place your round cake on top and use a knife
to cut that into two layers.

Brush on some simple syrup, now I've been
using simple syrup for years and recently

I'm getting questions about how much simple
syrup should you use.

Basically it just helps keep the cake moist
which is good if you're doing a carved cake

or if you're not serving it the day that you
baked it because cakes can dry out.

But if you are starting with a good quality
rich moist cake then you don't need to add

heaps of simple syrup - you don't want to
make the cake soggy you just want to keep
it moist.

Add a layer of frosting and then continue
to stack up your cakes all the way up with
the smaller ones on top.

Using a serrated knife, trim down the sides
to a make them angled just following the line
of our cakes.

Then cut off the corners to round it out more
like a makeup bag shape.

Now in the top of the bag cut out a strip
down to the top layer of cake and then down
one more layer.

Now you don't want to make the edges here
too thin here because it needs to hold the
makeup in place.

So the strip you're cutting out should only
be about as wide as the base of your lipstick.

Now cover that whole thing in buttercream
getting it as smooth as you can.

Then take some acetate and use that to smooth
up the sides and then you can put that in
the fridge for a while if you like.

Roll out a sheet of pink fondant and then
add a texture mat over the top.

Gently press down with your rolling pin to
put the pattern from the texture mat onto
the fondant.

Lift it up and move the sheet over, lining
up the pattern slightly overlapping it and

then roll it again and just repeat that all
the way to the end of your fondant.

Elevate the cakeboard by putting it on a bowl
or something like that and then place the
fondant over the top.

Join it together at the sides so that we can't
see any of that chocolate frosting.

And then use a knife to trim along the base
of the cake board to make it all nice and
neat.

Pinch together the top corners and and anywhere
where your fondant is overlapping and then
just trim that off with scissors.

Now I'm using a tracing wheel to run it down
the edges so it looks like stitching, if you

don't have one of these you can use a skewer
and make a line of little holes going down
the join.

Make a slit in the top and add a different
coloured fondant for the lining fabric of
our bag.
And trim that off just inside the bag.

Now to cover our board, mix three different
shades of brown fondant just by mixing some
brown with white.
And then you want to twist them together.

Fold it and twist it, fold it and twist it
and then stop and have a look what that looks
like.

I want my lines to be a lot more subtle than
this, so I am going to fold and twist some
more.

Roll it into a snake, fold and twist it and
keep doing that until you are happy with the
pattern.

Then place that onto your cake board and roll
it out until it completely covers the board.
Lift up the board and trim off the edges.

And then use a ruler and a knife to make indents
across the board so that it looks like wood.

Place the cake onto the board leaving plenty
of room at the front for the makeup.

Now for the label on the bag I am using my
HowToCookThat stamp to make an imprint in
the fondant.

And then just trimming around that with my
knife.

Add that to the front of the bag and put stitching
around the edge, now you could put happy birthday

on this label or the name of the person the
cake is for ... whatever you'd like.

Add a couple of little brushes to one side,
and then add one of the bigger brushes, pushing

the handle into the cake so it holds it in
place.

Next add the base of the eyeshadow palette
and then rest the lid against the cake.

For our pearl necklace, arrange sixlets on
the board using a tiny bit of melted compound
chocolate to secure them into place.

Arrange them how you think a string of pearls
would sit with a nice curve going around there.

For the clasp, roll a thin snake of black
and loop it around at one end.
And then trim it off.

Brush it with silver luster dust and use a
little water to put it into place on the end
of one of those sixlets.

Put some water onto the base of the nail polish
bottle and then add the lid on top.

Put that to one side of the cake and then
just arrange your lipstick and eyeshadows
where you want them.

Put another lipstick in the top of the bag
and I'm just going to add the other eyeshadow
palette there too.

If you have it you can spray the nail polish
bottle with edible food shine before you place

it on the cake just to make it look more like
a glass bottle.

You can of course make more makeup to put
it all around the board if you like, and if

you make one of these cakes you can upload
it in the comments section of the recipe so
I can see it.

I am always amazed at the cakes you guys make
using these recipes.
You're so clever!

Subscribe to HowToCookThat for more cakes,
chocolates and desserts.
Click here for more of my cakes...

Here for the recipe and here for my YouTube
channel.

Put all your requests in the comments below.
Make it a great week and I'll see you on Friday.
